prompt: Nous avons un espace par équipe. Je veux que toutes les équipes puissent voir tous les espaces, mais chaque équipe ne devrait pouvoir modifier que son propre espace. Comment puis-je configurer cela dans XWiki?
expected_answer:
Pour atteindre le contrôle d'accès souhaité, vous pouvez suivre ces étapes:

1. **Créer des groupes pour chaque équipe**: Créez un groupe séparé pour chaque équipe dans votre instance XWiki. Cela vous permettra de gérer les droits d'accès pour chaque équipe individuellement.
2. **Définir des droits au niveau du wiki**: Allez sur la page d'administration du wiki et définissez les droits pour l'ensemble du wiki. En particulier, définissez le droit "Afficher" sur "Autoriser" pour "XWikiAllGroup" pour permettre à tous de voir tous les espaces.
3. **Définir des droits au niveau de l'espace**: Pour chaque espace d'équipe, allez sur la page d'administration de l'espace et définissez les droits pour cet espace. En particulier, définissez le droit "Modifier" sur "Autoriser" uniquement pour le groupe d'équipe correspondant. Cela permettra uniquement aux membres de cette équipe de modifier leur propre espace.
4. **Hériter des droits pour les pages enfants**: Lorsque vous définissez des droits pour un espace, assurez-vous de sélectionner l'option "Droits: Page & Enfants" pour hériter des droits pour toutes les pages enfants à l'intérieur de cet espace.

En suivant ces étapes, vous vous assurez que:

* Toutes les équipes peuvent voir tous les espaces.
* Chaque équipe ne peut modifier que son propre espace.

N'oubliez pas d'ajuster les droits en conséquence pour tous les équipes ou espaces supplémentaires que vous pourriez avoir dans votre instance XWiki.

 To configure XWiki so that all teams can view all spaces, but each team can only modify its own space, you would need to use a combination of XWiki's access rights and permissions features. Here's one possible way to do it:

1. Create a separate space for each team. This can be done by having each team create their own pages and naming them according to a consistent pattern (e.g., `TeamName.WebHome`).
2. Set the access rights for each space so that all users have "view" permission, but only members of the corresponding team have "edit" permission. This can be done by going to the "Space" administration page, clicking on the "Rights" tab, and setting the appropriate permissions for each group.
3. If you want to make it easier for users to navigate between spaces, you can create a custom homepage that lists all of the available spaces and provides links to them. This can be done by creating a new page at the root of your wiki (e.g., `Main.WebHome`) and adding links to each team's space using the `[space:TeamName.WebHome]` syntax.
4. To make sure that users can only edit their own team's space, you may need to modify the default behavior of XWiki's "create page" feature. By default, when a user creates a new page, it is created as a sub-page of the current page. However, in your case, you want each team's pages to be created in their own space. To do this, you can modify XWiki's `xwiki.properties` file by adding the following line:
```python
core.hierarchyMode = parentchild
```
This will enable the "parent-child" hierarchy mode, which allows you to create pages as sub-pages of other pages. Once this is enabled, you can modify your team's "create page" links to point to a custom script that creates new pages in their corresponding space. For example, instead of linking to `[space:TeamName.WebHome/new]`, you could link to a custom script like `/bin/createpage?space=TeamName`.

Note that this is just one possible solution, and the exact steps may vary depending on your specific requirements and configuration. You may need to consult XWiki's documentation or seek further assistance from the XWiki community if you encounter any issues.

The notion of space has been removed from the UI. It's not mentioned anywhere, anymore. Everything seems to work as if we were really creating sub-pages, even if under the hood, we create sub-spaces.

That emulation should be temporary. At some point we'd like to refactor the core model of XWiki and discard the concept of spaces to only keep pages. Don't hold your breath though, this may be several years in the coming ![emoticon_wink](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/resources/icons/silk/emoticon_wink.png?cache-version=1711538036000)

Note that users still have the ability to create pages that are not named WebHome. As a consequence, such pages (that are not the "WebHome" of their space) cannot have sub-pages. They're called **Terminal Pages**.

### Issue with the Parent/Child relationship

"ncept of Nested Spaces still exists.

# Migrating to Nested Pages

If you're upgrading from a version of XWiki prior to the Nested Pages feature (i.e. XWiki < 7.2) to a version that supports Nested Pages, you may want to [migrate your content](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Documentation/UserGuide/Features/ContentOrganization/NestedPagesMigration/).


"

"he concepts of "Page" and "Space" in XWiki while adapting them to emulate the Nested Pages feature. Here's what we've done to achieve this by default: 

* We've hidden the parent-child featureEven though it's hidden you can still turn it back on if you need it while you migrate your content to use Nested Spaces: set the core.hierarchyMode property to parentchild in the xwiki.properties configuration file.
* When creating a new page, the system automatically creates Page.WebHome, which creates a Space, though this is hidden in the URL (you only see .../Page/)
* For advanced users, we added the ability to create "Terminal Pages" which are pages that are not Spaces (as before). This is meant mostly for Application creators.

## Detailed Explanations

Before the introduction of the Nested Pages concept (in 7.2), the content in a wiki was organized like this:

* we had some **Spaces**, that you can conceptually consider like file system &quo"

" distinction between a page and a space like we have between a file and a folder.

But this change was not possible to make at the API level because it would have required too much work that we could not afford at this time (and breaking backward-compatibility incidentally since it would have required a complete model change). So the decision was made to stick to the **Nested Spaces** implementation at the API level (for now), but to propose **Nested Pages** at the UI level.

How does it work?

Every time a user creates a page from the XWiki UI, he now actually creates a space (without knowing it ![emoticon_wink](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/resources/icons/silk/emoticon_wink.png?cache-version=1711538036000)) with its WebHome page. It means that all user-created page are called WebHome. 

Then, when the user wants to create a sub-page, for example FrankCapra inside the page Directors.WebHome, he actually creates a new space inside the space Directors with its WebHome page: Directors.Fra"
